title: Wall Clock

thumbnail.alt_text: Golden-colored, ornate wall clock adorned with golden flourishes, a bent figure with an arrow at top.

artist_display:
Case attributed to Jean-Pierre Latz
French, c. 1691–1754
Clockwork made by Francis Bayley 
Belgian, active 18th century
Paris, France
description: An exuberant and lavish example of the French Rococo style, this sculptural wall clock epitomizes the extravagant era of Louis XV (r. 1715–74). Festooned with ormolu (gilt bronze) swirls and floral swags, the clock required the collaboration of numerous specialized artisans. Its case, candelabra, and wall bracket were created by the eminent Jean-Pierre Latz, who was appointed ébéniste (furniture maker) to the king in 1741. The clock’s eight-day movement was manufactured in the Flemish city of Ghent by Francis Bayley, possibly a member of the large London dynasty of clockmakers of that name. Opulent clocks such as this did more than tell time; they delighted the ear with music (six melody titles are engraved in the dial’s arch) and dazzled the eye with dramatic scenes. Here the Greek god Apollo is poised at the top of the clock case to slay the serpent Python. The space between the clock and the wall bracket was cleverly used to suggest the beast’s home, the cave of Mount Parnassus in Greece. In the triangular base are the faces of Zeus, symbolizing time, and Hera, presiding over marriage and childbirth. They are surmounted by two small coats of arms belonging to the Flemish bride and groom whose union the clock was probably created to celebrate.
medium_display: Oak, tortoiseshell, kingwood, brass, gilt bronze, and glass
publication_history:
Henry Hawley, "Jean-Pierre Latz, Cabinetmaker," The Bulletin of the Cleveland Museum of Art, Vol. 57, No. 7 (Sep-Oct 1970): pp. 226-27, cat. no. 14 (ill.).

John Keefe, "An Eighteenth Century French Wall Clock Attributed to Jean-Pierre Latz," Bulletin of the Art Institute of Chicago, Vol. 70, No. 1 (Jan-Feb 1976): pp. 4-7 (ill.).

John Keefe, Selected Works of 18th Century French Art in the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 1976); p. 151; cat. no. 252 (ill.).

Ian Wardropper and Lynn Springer Roberts, European Decorative Arts in the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 1991), pp. 54 (detail), 55-56, 57 (ill.).

The Art Institute of Chicago, The Essential Guide, 4th Edition, (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 2015), p. 132 (ill.).
exhibition_history: AIC, Selected Works of 18th Century French Art in the Collections of the Art Institute of Chicago, January 24 to March 28, 1976.
